I heard somewhere or other that your book of essays was refused by Holt. Is this true? I think that I can place it for you with Houghton Mifflin if you care to send it to me. I was so immensely struck with those essays which I saw last year, and I think there should be no difficulty in placing them. I spoke to Ferris Greenslet about them last year, but naturally you preferred to send them where "Hymen" was published. However, if Holt does not want them, do send them to me, for I am quite sure I can land them with Houghton Mifflin.

I had a letter from Winifred the other day. She seems to have rushed all over Europe and Asia with a suit-case. I was afraid she was very much offended with me because I told her she would have to change certain things in her book of poems if she wanted them published over here. Since then she has sent me a portion of the manuscript in this little pamphlet "Arrow Music," and she has done practically what I suggested she do, and I think this little book is very charming.

Are you still in Switzerland, and what are your plans? I have been reading your selections in the "Miscellany" with great interest. I particularly like "Holy Satyr." How you think of the words you use, I do not know; it is a perfect marvel to me, and a perfect delight. "Heliodora" is a very strange thing, but a very interesting one, but rather unlike you, I think. "Toward the Piraeus" is the best thing you have done in rhyme. I like your method of rhyming or not as you happen to feel like, rhyming in some sentences and not in others. The series, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, with which your selection ends, is, I believe, the best of this collection, and No. 3 in hers is so charmingly rhymed. Your work with rhyme, which appears all through these selections, is very interesting to me. You certainly can write, Hilda, and nobody knows it better than I.

I do not think the "Miscellany" on the whole is bad. Conrad Aiken is too long-winded, one cannot even read him, and I am not a great admirer of Sara Teasdale, and I think Alfred Kreymborg falls down in his selections far below his best self, and Oppenheim is negligible, but on the whole I think the book looks pretty well. The truth of the matter is that we American poets of to-day are so diverse in the way we write that I do not think we fit together in a book very well. For that reason I think we are less homogenous than the Georgian Anthology, but personally I think so much better that even if the reader gets a jar going from one selection to another, he nevertheless gets a feeling of variety and profusion which is very effective.

Do write me and tell me what you are doing and what your plans for the Winter are. I suppose there is no hope of your coming over here; I wish there were. And, as I said before, do send me your essays and see if I cannot land them with Houghton Mifflin. With a great deal of love in which Mrs. Russell joins,
